prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SN 1978K Band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe SN 1978K to an rms of 0.025 mJy in Band 3.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Using standard observing parameters for a continuum source.

The source has a 10 mas extent at 8.4 GHz; it is assumed it will not be resolved by ALMA at this time, and we assume it is a point source.
We do not place any constraints on the antenna configuration or the timing of the ALMA observations. The four bands can be done at different times.

All the continuum fluxes are estimated assuming a -0.90 power law extrapolation from our ATCA millimeter detections, as shown in Figure 2.
If instead there is a steep roll-over in the spectrum, the RMS ~ 0.050 mJy in the four spectral windows will determine its location.
High S/N will ensure a good measurement of the millimeter spectrum and permit future studies of the spectral evolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SN 1978K Band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe SN 1978K to an rms of 0.025 mJy in Band 7.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Using standard observing parameters for a continuum source.

The source has a 10 mas extent at 8.4 GHz; it is assumed it will not be resolved by ALMA at this time, and we assume it is a point source.
We do not place any constraints on the antenna configuration or the timing of the ALMA observations. The four bands can be done at different times.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose high signal-to-noise observations in ALMA bands 3, 4, 6, and 7 of SN 1978K, a remarkable Type IIn supernova that remains bright at X-ray through radio wavelengths 37 years after its explosion. Motivated by our Australia Telescope Compact Array detections of the target at 34 and 94 GHz in September 2014, we aim to characterise the spectral energy distribution between 90 and 350 GHz. SN 1978K is the first old extragalactic supernova (or young SNR) to be detected in the millimeter, apart from SN 1987A. Thus observations of SN 1978K will serve as a pathfinder for younger supernovae. Furthermore, our ongoing program of multi-wavelength observations has shown that now is a particularly important time to study the source: our recent X-ray and UV/optical observations have shown an onset of chromatic fading, after these remained constant for a decade.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astrophysics Research Centre, Queen's University Belfast
Centre for Space Research, North-West University
